comments.commentBody:
On my 18-day round the world trip, I was concerned about that first 24-hours thing, particularly as most places I visited for about 48 hours total. Pre-planning was the key. I did a fair bit of online research to make sure I knew the most efficient way to get from the airport to the hotel in each of nine destinations. Most were nice and cheap (trains from airport to and from downtown in Hong Kong, Paris, London), almost all the rest were taxis, which were fast and not tooexpensive (Cairo, Singapore, Istanbul, Bruges) and one wonderfully expensive private water taxi direct to my hotel in Venice (had to do it). Main thing for me was maximizing my time on the ground in each destination, and knowing in advance not only the how but the where and how often of the airport transportation made a huge difference.

Detailed planning is critical for round the world travel. Almost as important: being flexible, changing your plans where needed and making the most of every stop by checking local maps and guides (particularly transportation options) in advance of your arrival. “Know before you go” is a well-worn phrase, but, on a trip like this, it made all the sense in the world!

A final note on jet lag, or lack of it. A lot of my traveling is walking, sightseeing and being out and about. Despite the time differences, my first priority was getting out and seeing things. No matter how tired I was, I pushed myself to observe local time for my eating and sleeping cycles. It worked really well. I was never overly tired or disoriented, nor did I have any trouble sleeping; I was out like a light every night!

Read more and see tons of pics from the trip in my book for iPad: Around The World In 18 Days. Please check it out at http://www.aroundtheworldbook.com
Happy Travels!

Re Comment #87:  Obama IS the problem.  He misrepresented his beliefs (he seems to have none), he has failed to lead.  He is a fraud and a wimp.  Romney is no better; so what?  He is at least up front about being a Republican, whereas Obama is a Republican in Democratic clothes. Consequently, he's become the Emperor in no clothes. And please, let's once and for all get over that piety, "Don't let the perfect be the enemy of the good."  Too often that is used to justify accepting a totally unacceptable solution because we don't have the guts to go for the gold. Not only does Obama not have the moral courage and intestinal fortitude to fight for the best solutions, he doesn't even have what it takes to fight for a good solution.  He has to go.  If the Democratic Party is to have any chance at all to retain the White House, the must throw open the doors to alternative candidates. Obama is an incumbent, not a monarch or a pope, and we should not be manipulated into thinking he shouldn't or can't be challenged, and successfully challenged.

If all of this was to placate the rich, well Wall Street certainly showed its opinion of the deal today. And for Jerez (#465), as it turned out today, US Gov't bonds had so much global demand that the interest rates went even lower. The only winners were the people who have bought gold (flogged by Glenn Beck).

The Democratic high ground is CHINA.  The reason we have high unemployment is because everything we buy is made in China. A country that does not make anything cannot produce wealth. China, on the other hand, is booming. They are next in line to become the economic powerhouse of the world leaving us in the dust.

You know what you can do with Moody's ratings? Garbage. This is the same rating agency that gave triple A's, up to a few days before the bubble bursted no less, the to all those sub prime loan derivatives that Wall Street was selling that got the USA into this whole economic mess. Moody's should be investigated for their too close for comfort relations with the corporations that they rate. Just pay them off and they will give you a triple A.

To all of the Obama apologists I would simply say this:

In every single important issue that he has faced, this President has let the Republicans frame the debate to create false choices. Then he walks into the room with upturned palms like he's Alfred E. Neuman and gives us the hey-this-is-the-best-I-could-do speech.

What nonsense.

This is a man who routinely filled football stadia during the '08 campaign. Has he ever once gotten out in front of an issue, framed it, and then dared the opposition to tangle with him? Has he? Ever?

I rest my case.

Bernie Sanders gets my write-in vote in '12. He tells it like it is.

Our President is a centrist Republican. That's not what he sold me during the campaign, it's not why I voted for him, and that's not who I think the country needs at the moment.
And this makes a difference to the unemployed; how?

This circus will be forgotten once the next crisis appears.  However, the broad public anger against bankers and Government officials will not dissipate by the elections .... there is no reason for it to be let go .... this anger has legs because no one has taken the heat for the bubble, its collapse, and the bailouts.  Plus, there has been no shared sacrifice, which is allowing, even encouraging, the anger to mutate and spread.  I suspect an election result quite different from that which most are expecting.  Business as usual?  I'll be surprised.

we said yrs back that there would be no middle class after the Bush Adm.......didn't matter who became the next Pres considering the damage the Bush Adm had ALREADY done.......and where were these tea partiers when all that spending was going on..and is it a law not to tax the rich??

This latest (near) debacle is just another reminder (for me at least) the congress needs terms limits. Congress people wouldn't worry about posturing so much (and would worry more about helping the country) if they were lead by senior leaders who were not only thinking about their next fight to get re-elected. Of course, we might have to ease the recall process too for congress people too, but I think it'd be worth it to avoid dysfunction.

@Wayne #28 "Why do baby boomers think everyone cares about their youth?"
We don't think everyone cares; we know we care and there's a whole lot of us. When you are older I hope you have an interesting and inspiring youth to look back on.
Can someone explain why Marion Nestle is "worried" that mainland Chinese people seem to be pleased with KFC?  Is Nestle also worried that Americans eat Chinese food?

As a youngish widow (48 now, 39 when my husband died of cancer), I find the men bashing in many of these comments disturbing.  Everyone grieves differently and no one can no what is truly in another's heart.  After my husband died, I asked my children's therapist if she knew other widows/widowers of a similar age with young children who would be interested in forming a group.  The group she put together was myself another woman and two men.  Those two men adored their wives and grieved deeply for them.  We all missed the love and companionship of our spouses.  Their wives both had careers and the men were excellent cooks so their grief was not about the loss of a "cook and housekeeper."  These men are both remarried now (as is the other woman in the group) and I know for all of them that the new marriages have brought much joy to their lives but not an end to the greif they feel for their former spouses.   We should aspire to more compassion and less judgement when discussing the grief of others.

Need to put these crooks in jail. It's about time the government start checking on the billing practice of Doctors and Medicare Providers. If they would put them in jail. They would quit cheating the system.

I'm apparently the other person in the universe that did not like HP7-II. Not having read the book nor waited excitedly for the movie, I had no expectations and none were met. For me for a movie to be good it should stand on its own, not requiring having seen a prequel or having read a book to know exactly what's going on. HP&-II gets pretty low marks on these two points. This movie is mostly a special effects extravaganza. They were pretty good but then almost nothing is impossble with computers these days. Compare these with the special effects of The Wizard of Oz or early Hitchcock films when they actually had to do something (I mean, flying monkeys!). Acting? Separate out all the running, falling and flying and there is not a great deal of acting to consider, is there? I was not overwhelmed with the performance of Daniel Radcliffe. I wonder how he feels about it. I guess I would just echo the words of reviewer Robert Roten of The Laramie Movie Scope, "Thank God it is finally over."
Endangered artifact:  the Helper (Utah) Arts and Music Festival.  State money?  We didn't cut our state arts budget this year, because there wasn't one.

The Board of Directors of this "nonprofit" organization should be brought in for questioning and possible prosecution for dereliction of fiduciary duties. Former board president Marcella Fava deserves particular blame.

These kinds of Medicaid and Medicare abuse and fraud are frighteningly widespread. Why is there no crackdown or enforcement? The penalties for "upcoding," overbilling, etc, are little compared to the enormous profits to be made. Look at Prime Healthcare in California, which has ripped off Medical for millions over the past several years. Its director, Dr. Prem Reddy should be in prison -- but at worst, will get a fine.

Getting information about the ongoing Fukushima disaster may become even more difficult due to the passage of "The Computer Network Monitoring Law” in Japan. On Friday, July 15, the Ministry of Industry and Trade – Agency for Natural Resources and Energy, opened a call for bids for contractors to monitor blogs and tweets posting about nuclear power and radiation as part of the “Nuclear Power Safety Regulation Publicity Project”. It has been reported that since March 11th YouTube videos containing footage or comments unfavorable to Tokyo Electric Power Company (TEPCO) or the Japanese government have been removed within several hours of their posting.

With contractors hired to monitor blogs such as this site http://ex-skf.blogspot.com/ we may lose access to sources of up-to-date information from Japan. Blogs are filling the large gaps in the US media's coverage of such incidents as radioactive leaf compost spreading to schools and possibly irradiating children as they planted flowers as part of the school curriculum. That large gap allows people in the US to believe that what happened in Fukushima is a past event, rather than an ongoing unmitigated disaster that continues unabated as shown by TEPCO's August 1st announcement of the highest recorded levels of radiation resulting from the meltdowns at the nuclear plant.

Gold's value beyond its utility can easily be determined by the will of the super wealthy class.

A gold standard would only serve to increase their influence.
So Ron Paul wants to go back to gold coins as currency? I doubt there is enough gold in the world to replace even just the greenback.

Sooner or later a nation will base their national currency on gold again. It is just a matter of time.  FDR used the gold standard to help stabilize our economy after coming out of the great depression.  Obama seems to be continuing FDR's plan.  We better be the first nation to go back on the gold standard, to ensure the strength of our currency, we need to have the flexibility of using gold to our advantage.

problem is that the price of gold has shot up so much that it, like everything, will soon collapse under its own weight. Someone will just say - its not worth THAT much and stop buying, plateau, then fall. So now is not the moment.

There are a lot of problems with the worlds banking system: too big to fail, crazy compensation which encourages short termism, lack of regulation of derivatives, and riduculous levels of gearing.
Free floating exchange rates however is NOT one of them. Currency speculation can only last as long as a favorable differential.

In ancient times rulers would dilute the precious metal in their coins while presenting them as if they had not been diluted.

Today we have no such clumsy encumberances, we just print more money and dilute it on schedule, the prefered rate being 2% per year. This allows politicians to buy favor with the inflated proceeds without raising overt taxes, instead relying on inflation that taxes invisibly to the layman.

A zero inflation attempt would deprive politicians of their sinister method. Don't count on that happening until an inflationary collapse settles the issue. Then we can start over again with gold backing.
Egypt by 2012 will be back to where it was at the start; simply because their in-between takeover men are watching Syria/Iran & then will consider taking over Egypt again.
